statement.tex: %text Find the points on the line % \qquad\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2} \\ %text at a distance $5$ units from the point $P\left(1,3,3\right)$. %

step.context: %text How could one express the coordinates of any point on line $\dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}$ in terms of a single variable $k$? %
step.reason: \begin{align} \dfrac{x+2}{3}=\dfrac{y+1}{2}=\dfrac{z-3}{2}=k\, \text{(say)} \end{align} \\ %text Using the above equation, we can express the $x$, $y$ and $z$ coordinates of any point on the given line in terms of $k$. Therefore, % x=3k-2, y=2k-1, z=2k+3.

step.context: %text If the distance of point $P(1,3,3)$ from point $(3k-2, 2k-1, 2k+3)$ is $5$ units, what is the value of $k$? %
step.reason: %text Distance between two points $(x_1, y_1,z_1)$ and $(x_2, y_2, z_2)$ in 3D space is given by, % D=\sqrt{\left(x_2-x_1\right)^2+\left(y_2-y_1\right)^2+ \left(z_2-z_1\right)^2} \\ %text For the distance of $5$ units between $(1,1,3)$ and $(3k-2, 2k-1, 2k+3)$, we have, % \begin{align} &(3k-3)^2+(2k-4)^2+(2k)^2=5^2 \\ \implies & 17k^2-34k=0 \\ \implies & 17k(k-2)=0 \\ \implies & k=0,2 \end{align} \\ %text Its logical for there to be two values of $k$ since there may be two points on the line at a distance of $5$ units (unless ??). The points are $(-2,-1,3)$ and $(4,3,7)$. %
